carousels.name: what-makes-a-good-cto
carousels.description: The skills a CTO needs beyond just coding

slides.topText: It's probably easy to find a techie.
slides.bottomText: But what you actually need in a CTO is more than just a technical background.

slides.topText: They can't just be junior level in tech.
slides.bottomText: They need to be mid-to-senior level.

slides.topText: They need product thinking.
slides.bottomText: Which honestly, as software engineers, we're not trained in. You have to learn it on the side.

slides.topText: You have to do side projects that teach you:
slides.bottomText: How do I find a problem? What are the minimum viable features? How do I validate it?

slides.topText: These are not things we do as software engineers.
slides.bottomText: We sit there and wait for features to appear in a ticket.

slides.topText: Cool. Code. Ship.
slides.bottomText: Not my problem anymore. Tell me what to do next.

slides.topText: So you need somebody with product thinking
slides.bottomText: AND the ability to pitch — to explain tech in layman's terms.

carousels.name: vibe-coding-not-enough
carousels.description: Why no-code and vibe coding won't scale

slides.topText: A lot of non-technical founders think they don't need a CTO at all.
slides.bottomText: They truly believe that vibe coding, no-code tools is enough to start a tech startup.

slides.topText: Oh yeah, I know what's an API. I know what's a database.
slides.bottomText: There are tools to get these things. Voila. I'm a tech.

slides.topText: They truly believe the no-code platform will handle all of this for them.
slides.bottomText: But when asked: what happens when you scale to users beyond this region?

slides.topText: For us it's intuitive — data availability, provisioning.
slides.bottomText: But this is not intuitive to the layman because they've never encountered it.

slides.topText: A lot of no-code platforms are just wrappers over existing AI models.
slides.bottomText: They aren't equipped to create apps that scale.

slides.topText: These founders have never worked in a tech company before.
slides.bottomText: They don't know about unit testing, integration testing, end-to-end testing.

carousels.name: engineering-not-coding
carousels.description: Why software is engineering, not just coding

slides.topText: That's why it's called engineering.
slides.bottomText: It's more than coding — it's about the architecture.

slides.topText: It's like building a bridge.
slides.bottomText: You can't change one small part and ignore the rest.

slides.topText: You're not considering the whole physics of it.
slides.bottomText: How it'll break or anything.

slides.topText: Non-coders see it as: as long as the app looks like it works...
slides.bottomText: They don't understand the back end.

slides.topText: They're not properly educated or trained in this.
slides.bottomText: So they don't see it as engineering. They see it as coding.

slides.topText: A lot of my non-technical friends say 'Oh, you're a coder.'
slides.bottomText: They don't say engineer because it's an unfamiliar term.

slides.topText: It shows in how they see vibe coding:
slides.bottomText: I'm building an app from zero to one and it works. What about the secrets? What about security?

slides.topText: I've been seeing fractional CTOs becoming more common.
slides.bottomText: A company hires someone as a CTO on a part-time basis.

slides.topText: A fractional CTO can advise multiple startups at once.
slides.bottomText: All the way from seed stage to Series B, C, D.

slides.topText: It's kind of like a lawyer on retainer.
slides.bottomText: You only call them when something happens.

slides.topText: For seed-stage startups, they'll ask for technical strategy:
slides.bottomText: Which developers do I hire? What tech stack do I need?

slides.topText: Once that groundwork is set up, they're like 'Okay, bye-bye.'
slides.bottomText: Until the next round: 'We need to refactor. What should we do?'

slides.topText: It's probably like a temporary CTO.
slides.bottomText: While you're finding someone really invested in the idea, get someone to solve immediate problems.
